text: WALTER VALE, sixty-two, is standing by the window of his modestly furnished Colonial house. He is holding a glass wine and peering out through the drapes. After a few moments an OLD CAR pulls up. A slightly overweight WOMAN gets out of the car. She starts to walk to the house. Walter steps back from the window and waits. The doorbell rings. Walter takes a last sip of wine and sets the glass down on the end table. And then he goes to the door and o it.
Mr. Vale?
Yes.
Hello. I'm Barbra Watson. Nice to meet you.
Yes. Come in.
Thank you.
She steps into the house and Walter shuts the door. They stand there awkwardly. Barbara is tightly wound and overcompensates with a forced pleasantness.
Can I take your coat?
No, thank you.
OK. Would you like anything to drink?
No. (Beat) Shall we get started?
Walter and Barbara sit side by side in a very close proximity.
Let's try it again.
The same thing?
Yes. Remember, fingers curved. Like a tunnel.
OK.
Walter starts to play the piano. It's a lesson in progres They are sitting at a beautiful GRAND PIANO but Walter is only a beginner. And not a very good beginner.
Don't flatten.
Walter keeps playing.
Make room for the train.
Walter stops.
What?
I said "make room for the train." It's something that I tell my kids. If you curve your fingers like this... (She demonstrates) Then the train can pass through the tunnel.
She passes her pencil through her curved fingers. Walter looks at her for a long moment.
Walter walks Barbara to the front door. He opens it and t hands Barbara some money. 3
Here.
Thank you. Next Tuesday at the same time?
No. I don't think I'm going to continue with our lessons.
Oh, no. Are you giving up?
No.
Barbara gets the point. He is stopping with her, not the lessons.
Oh. OK. Goodbye.
Goodbye.
Barbara walks out the door and then turns before Walter s it.
Mr. Vale? If I may ask, how many teachers have you had before me?
Four.

Well, for what it's worth, it's difficult to learn an instrument at your age. Especially if you don't possess a natural gift for it. I'm not saying this to be mean. But if you do decide to give up then I would really like to buy your piano. It's a beautiful instrument.
Walter nods, not quite sure how to receive the comment.
Goodbye.
Barbara turns and leaves. Walter shuts the door. 4
Walter stands before a half-empty class. He is wrapping u lecture on economic theory. There is nothing inspiring ab it.

East Asia's experience is really the exception to the rule, because the conditions there that made trade liberalization for the Middle East successful weren't present in the developing countries in sub- Saharan Africa, and in Central and South America.
Walter walks across the campus.
Walter sits in a meeting with seven other COLLEAGUES.
Walter is staring out the window in his simple but very l in office. Classical music plays softly in the background knock at the door.
Come in.
A STUDENT opens the door and enters.
Hi.
He sits down and sets a paper on the desk.
Sorry it's late.
Why is it late?
I had some personal things to deal with. 5
Walter hands back the paper.
I'm sorry. I can't accept it now.
But...
I'm sorry.
Walter goes back to work. The Student sits stunned for a moment and then gets up and picks up his paper. He opens door and then stops.
You know you still haven't given us a syllabus.
(Lying) I know.
The Student shakes his head and leaves without another wo
Walter pulls into the driveway of his house. He gets out, grabs his belongings out of the back seat and walks insid

Walter is making dinner. Classical music plays from the o room. He adjusts the flame and covers a sauce pot. He lea against the counter and picks up a half empty bottle of w and pours some into his glass. He catches sight of A SMAL FRAMED PICTURE of him and HIS WIFE, smiling.
Walter sits at the piano and practices. It is still going badly. The wine glass sits on top of the piano. He lifts hand and inspects his "tunnel".
Walter is at his computer. He pulls up his YEAR SYLLABUS the computer and carefully changes 2005 to 2006. He saves His work is done. There is a knock at the door. 6
Yes.
The door opens and Walter's colleague, CHARLES VAN HORN s in.
Hello Walter.
Charles.
I'm sorry to interrupt.
That's OK.
Walter, Shelley can't make it down to the NYU conference to present your paper. I'm going to need you to cover for her.
Why can't she go?
She's been put on bed rest until she has the baby.
Walter is caught off guard.
When?
Next week. We'll cover your class and make the arrangements.
I wish I could, but now is not a very good time, Charles.
I understand but you co-authored the paper and the Dean wants it presented. He wants to keep Shelley on track for tenure.
I just don't think I can with the start of classes and my book. 7
You're only teaching one class, Walter.
So I can stay focused on my writing. I'd really rather not go right now.
I'm sorry but there really isn't another option at this point.
Walter is trapped. He comes clean.
Charles, the truth is this is really Shelley's paper. I just agreed to co-author it because she asked me to. I'm not really prepared to present it.
That may be the case but you are the co-author and she can't go. Look Walter, you can take it up with the Dean if you want, but, as your friend, I wouldn't advise it. Not with that argument.
Walter just stares him.
Good bye.
And Charles is gone, shutting the door behind him.

location: NEW LONDON, THE BLIND TIGER BAR

text: Walter sits at the end of a bar at a local pub. He is rea the newspaper. KAREN, a 44-year-old bartender, is talking a BlONDE HAIRED WOMAN at other end of the bar. The wall is covered with HAND DRAWN CARICATURES OF REGULA PATRONS. A WAITER hands a plate of food to Karen. She wal down the bar and sets it in front of Walter.
Here you go, cutey.
Thanks. 8
So I thought you forgot about me. Where've you been hiding?
Karen automatically refills his wine glass.
Just busy with work.
Well you're never gonna make it on the wall with that excuse. I'm glad your back. Give a holler if you need anything. I'm just gabbing with one of my girlfriends.
OK.
She walks back down the bar. Walter starts to eat.
Two cars are parked in Walter's driveway.
Walter is packing, laying out his shirts on the bed. Afte moment, Karen walks in, drying her hair with a towel.
When are you going?
Today after class.
She takes her earrings of the night stand and puts them i
Sounds like fun. I'm gonna go have a cigarette. You want some coffee?
Yeah. Thanks.
Karen leaves. Walter keeps packing.
Walter sits at a table and eats lunch alone. 9
Walter walks across the parking lot and gets into his car
Walter drives along the highway. He notices a SIGN which reads "Support Our Troops!"
Walter's car drives down the F.D.R Highway. INT. WALTER'S CAR - DUSK. Walter drives through the small busy streets of the East Village.

location: NEW YORK CITY, EAST VILLAGE, PARKING GARAGE

text: Walter pulls into a parking garage. He gets out and takes ticket from the attendant. He grabs his bag and briefcase from the back seat.
He walks down the street, taking in the sights and sounds the city.
Walter walks out of a liquor store with a SMALL BROWN BAG
Walter arrives at a classic tenement building. He looks u the building as if inspecting it. He takes out his keys. He opens the door and walks in.
Walter walks into the well-lit but dingy foyer.   A YOUNG brushes by him. 10
He arrives at the second floor and stops in front of a do He unlocks the door and walks in.
Walter steps into the apartment and drops his bags. He immediately notices that the kitchen light is on. Somethi is not right.
Hello?

He turns on the living room light and crosses to the kitc table and sets the brown bag down. It's then that he noti some fresh flowers on the kitchen table. He looks slightl confused. He looks around the apartment. There is an UPRI PIANO along one wall.
Hello?

There is no answer. He walks down a LONG HALLWAY and look the kitchen. Nothing. He walks over to the FIRST BEDROOM looks inside. There are signs of someone living there. He looks in the SECOND BEDROOM. He sees nothing. Suddenly he hears the sound of running water from the bathroom. He notices a light under the door. He walks to bathroom and listens. A faucet is turned and the water st running. He opens the door and looks in.
A YOUNG BLACK WOMAN is soaking in the bath tub.   She see Walter and screams.
Walter screams too and then slams the door, stepping back into the hallway.
Stay away from me!
She has a West African accent. 11
It's OK. I'm not going...
Leave me alone! My boyfriend is coming home!
I'm not going to hurt you.
Who are you? What are you doing in here!?
This is my apartment.
What do you mean? This apartment does not belong to you. How did you get in?
My name is Walter Vale. I have keys. It's my...
Suddenly Walter is pushed up against the wall. Hard.
What the fuck?!
A very angry, YOUNG MIDDLE EASTERN MAN is in Walter's fac He grabs Walter violently by the collar and shakes him.
Who are you?! Zainab?!
I'm in here! He is crazy!
Stop it! I am not...
The Young Middle Eastern Man slams him against the wall. more of a warning shot then a violent act. Walter is terrified.
Shut up!
OK. OK.
(In French) Tarek. What is happening?
(In French) Are you OK?
(In French) I'm fine.
(In French) Who is this?
(In French) I have no idea! I was in the bath and he was just standing there.
(Shaking Walter) Did you touch her?! Did you touch her?!
No! No!
Zainab opens the door.
(In French) He didn't touch me! But how did he get in? He said he has keys.
Do you have keys?
Yes! Yes! I have keys. It's my apartment.
Tarek stares at Walter, trying to make sense of it.
(in French) What does he mean it's his apartment?
I don't know! Show me your keys! 13
Walter reaches into his pocket and holds up his keys.
This is my apartment. I've owned it for twenty-five years.
So why haven't you been here!?
I live in Connecticut. I haven't used it in a long time.
Walter is starting to get through.
Are you friends with Ivan?
Ivan? Who is Ivan?
Tarek is getting nervous.
(In French) I knew this would happen! He probably called the police.
This catches Tarek's attention.
(to Walter) Did you call the police?
Walter hesitates.
No.
You didn't call the police?
No.
Tarek looks like he might belt Walter. Instead, he lets h go and quickly backs up. He paces while trying to gather thoughts. Walter doesn't move. Zainab runs into the bedro
And you don't know Ivan? 14
I don't know Ivan. Who is he?
He rented us this place. He said it belonged to his friend who was out of town.
I don't know who he is but this is my apartment. I assure you.
Tarek looks at Walter for a long moment. It's clear that telling the truth.
Shit!
(In French) I told you not to trust anyone. You never saw a contract.
Enough! OK. Look. We don't want any trouble. We will get out of your apartment. This is all a mistake. I'm sorry.
OK.
We will leave, OK?
Yes. OK.
Zainab emerges from the bedroom. She is dressed.
(In French) Where are we going to go?
(In French) I don't know but we have to go.
(In French) I know we have to go. I am not stupid! 15
Are you OK?
Yes. I'm just going to sit down.
Of course. Please.
Walter nods and then slowly walks down the hallway and si down. He is clearly shaken. Tarek shuts the front door.
I'm sorry if I hurt you. Are you sure that you're OK?
Yeah. I'm OK.
OK. Well, we'll pack up and get out.
Tarek walks back toward the bedroom. Walter tries to catc his breath.

Walter is sitting on the couch with a glass of wine. Tare enters and sets down a bag. He picks up TWO AFRICAN DRUMS next to the piano and places them by the front door. Zainab enters from the bedroom mumbling something in an African dialect. She drops a bag and crosses back to the bedroom.
I know I'm in trouble when she starts speaking Wolof.
How long have you lived here?
Two months. We will pay you if you want.
Walter doesn't respond. Zainab emerges from the bedroom a with the last bag. 16
(To Zainab) Is that everything?
I think so. Do you want to check!?
He hands her a SMALL PLASTIC BAG from a local grocery.
Here is the coffee you wanted.
She snatches it without a word.
(To Walter) OK. So we'll go. I am sorry again. Thank you for your understanding. Good bye.
Good bye.
They turn and exit. Walter gets up and walks over to the front door and locks it. He stands by the front door trying to process the events. Then something catches his attention.

Walter walks to the window and picks up a handcrafted, decorative FRAME off of the sill. It is a PHOTOGRAPH of T and Zainab. They are hugging each other and smiling. Walt looks down onto the street. He sees Zainab and Tarek exit the building and cross the street. Zainab's cart tips on the curb and the contents s out onto the sidewalk. Tarek quickly moves to help her. Zainab yells at him. Walter watches as they finally collect their belongings a move down the street.
Tarek has set his bags down in front of a closed store. H talking in a very agitated tone on his cell phone. Zainab stands by silently. 17
(In Arabic) Look I know. Come on man, it'll just be for a night or two until we figure something out. OK.
Tarek?
(In Arabic) Can you check and call me back? OK. Thanks.
Tarek?
What!?
Zainab points. Walter is standing there holding the frame photograph.
You left this at the apartment.
Tarek walks over and takes it.
Thanks.
Walter nods.
Do you know where you're going to stay tonight?
Yeah.
The lie is obvious. They are stuck. Walter just nods agai

Walter takes some books out of his briefcase. He crosses the bookshelf and sets them down. He notices a small stac CD's sitting on a shelf. He picks one of them up and star at the CD for a long moment.
You like classical music, huh? 18
Yes.
Walter sets down the CD.
Me too. Do you play piano?
No. (Beat) Do you?
Me? No. I play the djembe. Well, thanks again for letting us stay. You saved me a lot of trouble.
Walter nods.
See you in the morning.
OK. Good night.
Tarek goes to bed. Walter resumes his work.
Walter is lying in bed, unable to sleep. He can hear Tare and Zainab whispering and laughing.

location: WALTER'S APARTMENT, TAREK AND ZAINAB'S ROOM

text: Tarek and Zainab are lying in bed together.
Stop it, Tarek. He'll hear us.
Trust me. He's asleep.
You don't know that.
So let him hear. The guy probably needs some excitement. 19
I think he's probably had enough for one night.
Tarek nuzzles her. Zainab laughs but pushes him away.
Tarek. No!
Zainab sits up in the bed. Tarek relents and rolls onto h back.
What are we going to do, Tarek?
I don't know. We'll figure it out tomorrow. Who knows? Maybe he'll let us stay. He's not really using the place.
I don't want to be his roommate!
OK. OK. So we'll figure it out in the morning. I promise, habibti.
Zainab shakes her head.
Do you still love me?
Zainab looks at him.
No.
Really?
Zainab rolls over and straddles Tarek.
No. I don't love you.
She kisses Tarek.
Not even a little?
No. 20
She kisses him again.
So what is this?
She gets very close to his face.
It's your punishment.
But what about our roommate?
Shhh.
She kisses him long and hard. They start to make love.
Jacob walks outside with Sprinkles.
Walter is tying his tie in the mirror.
Walter walks out of his bedroom and runs into Zainab who leaving her bedroom at the same time. It's obvious that s was trying to avoid Walter.
Good morning.
Morning.
I made some coffee.
Thank you.
Have a good day.
Goodbye. 21
Walter leaves.
The Kimmel Center towers over Washington Square Park.
Walter is listening to the speaker.
That will be on the last day of conference. I hope you can all attend. And now I'd like to welcome my distinguished colleague and the winner of John Bates Clark Award, Stephen Kriegman.
STEPHEN KRIEGMAN strides to the podium. He is a good deal younger then Walter.
Thank you, Shiva. Good morning. It's a pleasure to be here.
Walter mingles at a reception. He is listening to another COLLEAGUE tell a story.
And so I just stood up and walked out!
The group laughs. Stephen Kriegman approaches and talks t the COLLEAGUE.
Jamie!
Stephen, how are you?
Walter walks off.
Walter eats dinner in a large, well appointed banquet roo Walter listens as a CHATTY MAN talks. 22
Walter is walking up the stairs carrying a briefcase. He passes a MIDDLE-AGED MAN who is walking down the stairs w a SMALL DOG on a leash.
Excuse me.
Walter stops and turns.
Yes.
Are you Mr. Vale?
Yes.
I thought so. How are you? It's me, Jacob Konigsberg. Do you remember me?
Walter doesn't.
I used to live here with my mother. Your wife used to give me piano lessons.
Oh. Right.
It has been a long time. I thought that maybe you sold the place. Oh. This is Sprinkles. (To the dog) Say "hi", Sprinkles. Is your wife here with you?
No. She passed away.
What?! No! I had no idea. I'm so sorry. She was such a nice lady. And I just loved listening to her play. 23
How's your mother?
She moved to Florida. Now I live here. It's nice. There are a lot of new faces. I hardly know anyone anymore. But I have Sprinkles so...
Nice to see you, Jacob.
You too, Mr. Vale. Goodbye. Welcome back.
Walter nods and keeps walking.
Walter walks into the apartment. No one else is there. He sets down his case and walks toward his bedroom but st at Tarek and Zainab's door, which is closed. He listens. Nothing.
Walter is reading over and "rehearsing" the paper that he to present.
(Sotto) It is important to distinguish between both our current political assessment and our...It is important to distinguish between our current political assessment...
He stops and crosses out the world "both". He continues reading.
Walter is practicing the piano. He continues to struggle. sits back and takes a break. He notices the drum next to piano. He looks at it for long moment and then continues playing. 24
Walter is lying in bed awake. He listens as Tarek and Zai come home.
Walter buys a newspaper.
Walter is back at the conference. He is listening to a presentation by a GERMAN ECONOMIST.

However, we do find that financial globalization can be beneficial under the right circumstances. Empirically, good institutions and quality of governance are crucial in helping developing countries derive the benefits of globalization.
Walter checks his watch. He is obviously bored.

Walter is sitting in the park and eating some Indian food from a local cart vendor. He finishes and drops it into t garbage can. He checks his watch and starts to head back toward the conference when a SOUND catches his attention.
Walter watches two young AFRICAN AMERICAN MEN drumming on BUCKETS with reckless abandon.
We should have them come play inside.
Walter turns. THREE COLLEAGUES from the conference are standing next to him.
Coming in? 25
Yes. In a minute. (Holding up his cell phone) I have to make a call.
See you inside.
Walter nods as the guys walk off. Walter watches them go. turns and watches the drumming again.
Walter arrives on the top floor. He can hear the drum bei played. He stops in front of his apartment. He listens fo moment and then slowly opens the door.
Tarek is playing his drum in his T-shirt and underwear. H sees Walter and finishes with a flourish.
Hey Walter. Welcome home.
Hi.
Tarek casually gets up and puts on his pants.
You're home early.
It was a half day.
How was the conference?
Fine.
Tarek buttons his pants.
Sorry about the pants. I've been playing like this since I was a kid.
Walter nods. 26
Hey. I think I might have a lead on a place in Brooklyn.
That's good. You can keep practicing if you like.
Really? It won't bother you?
No.   It's fine.
Great. Thanks. I'll keep my pants on.
Tarek laughs. Walter smiles.
Hey, Zainab's going to make dinner if you want to eat with us later.
OK. Thank you.
Walter walks into his bedroom. Tarek watches him go and t starts playing again.
Walter is lying down on his bed reading through his paper His foot is tapping to the rhythm of the drum.
Walter and Zainab are sitting at the dinner table finishi their meal. Tarek is on the phone in the living room spea in Arabic. He hangs up and rejoins the table.
I'm sorry. That was my mother. If I don't call her every day she thinks something happened to me.
Walter pours himself some wine. He offers some to Tarek. 27
Yeah. I'll have a bit. Thanks.
Zainab shoots Tarek a glance. Walter misreads it.
Are you sure that you wouldn't like some?
I don't drink.
(Jokingly) She is a good Muslim. I'm a bad one.
Walter nods. Zainab gets up and starts to clear the table
Are you finished?
Yes. Thank you. Here, let me...
It's the least I can do.
Her comment is more of an indictment than a pleasantry.
Well, thank you for the dinner. It was very good.
You're welcome.
She leaves the room.
So what's the conference about?
Economic Growth in Developing Nations.
That's us. (Pointing) Syria. Senegal. 28
So have you written some books?
Three. I'm working on my fourth.
Four books?! Great. My father was a writer. A journalist.
Is he still writing?
No. He died. Before we left Syria.
I'm sorry.
So am I.
Zainab enters.
Tarek. It's eight-thirty.
Oh. We have to go. (To Walter) I have a gig tonight.
Zainab starts to put on her coat.   Tarek picks up his dr
Walter, you can come if you want.
Zainab shoots Tarek a glance.
I have to get some work done but thank you.
OK. Well maybe another time
OK.
Bye. 29
Tarek and Zainab leave. Walter watches them go and then l around the empty apartment.
Tarek and Zainab are walking down the stairs.
(In French) Why did you invite him?
(In French) We're staying in his apartment. What could I do?
(In French) Well I would have been the one stuck sitting with him while you played your drum.
Tarek turns and looks at her very seriously.
You know you are very sexy when you're mad at me.
Zainab can't help but smile. Tarek starts to wrap his arm around her.
Hello.
Tarek and Zainab stop in their tracks, already three flig down. They both look up the stairwell. Walter is looking on them.
If you don't mind, I think I will come.
Tarek and Zainab share a quick look.
Cool.
Walter disappears back into the apartment. Zainab looks a Tarek. He shrugs. 30
Tarek's Jazz Trio is playing. Walter and Zainab sit at a small table in the back. Walter is rapt. Zainab is sketch She looks up from her pad and watches him before returnin her drawing.
Walter and Zainab are standing outside on the empty stree There's an awkward silence.
He's very good.
Yes.
The whole band is very good.
Yes.
And then nothing. Finally Tarek emerges.
Sorry guys. Let's go.
They walk down the street.
Walter is sitting in the park and eating PIZZA. This time is sitting directly across from the two African American drummers.
Walter walks into the apartment and sets down his briefca He notices Tarek's drum sitting in the middle of the room
Tarek?
No one answers. Walter walks down the hallway a bit.
Tarek? 31

Walter walks back into the living room and takes off his coat. He removes some papers from his briefcase and then notices the drum again. He sits down in the chair next to Tarek's drum. He takes drum between his legs and he hits it a few times. Then he starts to play. He stops and then he plays again. This time he is slightly more successful at finding a rhy He closes his eyes and bobs his head. He's really getting into it. He opens his eye's open and Tarek is standing in front of him. He has headphones around his neck. Walter jumps.
Oh. Hi.
It sounded good Walter.
Walter immediately stands.
Yeah. Well. I was just...I'm sorry if I...
Tarek walks over and grabs another chair from the kitchen table.
Don't be sorry. That's what it's there for.
Tarek sets the chair down and grabs the other drum from beside the piano.
I was lying on my bed listening to my music and then I was like "what's the crazy rhythm I'm hearing?".
Tarek sits down with the other drum facing Walter.
Sit. Come on. I'll show you.
Walter hesitates and then sits down.
Just put your feet flat on the ground. 32
Walter adjusts his feet.
Now take the drum between your legs. Like this.
Tarek grabs the drums with his knees. Walter follows.
Now you want to lift the inside edge off the ground with your ankles. Like this.
Walter watches Tarek and follows suit.
Great. Feel OK?
Yes.
OK. Now Walter, I know you're a very smart man but with the drum you have to remember not to think. Thinking just screws it up. OK?
OK.
Now just give it a couple of bangs.
Walter gives it a couple of hard bangs.
Not so hard. You're not angry at it.
Oh. Right.     Sorry.
He bangs it a few more times.
Better. Did you think?
No. 33

Good. Now one more thing, Walter. You listen to classical music so you think in fours. One. Two. Three. Four. Da. Da. Da. Da. This is an African drum. So we are gonna play in three's. Tat. Tat. Tat. You have to forget your classical. Leave it behind. Tat. Tat. Tat. One. Two. Three. Come on. Follow me.
Tarek bangs out a simple bass beat. Walter joins in.
Good. Good ear. Now keep going.
Walter loses the beat.   Tarek keeps playing.
Don't worry. Start again.
Walter tries again. And again. And then finally he gets i
Yeah! There it is. OK. Good. Now keep it going and I will do this.
Tarek riffs off of Walter's bass beat.
Yeah. That's it. Keep it going.
Zainab is closing up her booth. Another VENDOR walks by a says good bye. Zainab smiles and nods good bye.
Zainab is walking home with her supplies. Two NEW YORK PO OFFICERS are talking to THREE YOUNG HISPANIC KIDS. Zainab hesitates for the slightest moment before lowering her he and walking past.
Zainab enters the apartment and sees Walter drumming. His shirt is unbuttoned exposing his white undershirt. He sto He is breathing very hard and sweating. 34
Hello.
Hello. Where is Tarek?
She places her items down on the kitchen table and takes her coat. She looks around the apartment.
He went out. To look at another apartment.
She just looks at him with the drum. Walter is still out breath.
Are you OK?
Yeah. Tarek is teaching me the drum. I'm practicing. Don't worry, I'll keep my pants on.
Zainab looks shocked. Walter's attempt at levity has fall short.
What?
Nothing. I was just...nothing.
Zainab nods and walks into the kitchen.
Tarek is playing with his band. Walter is at the bar watching. He is unconsciously tapping along on the bar.
Tarek, Walter, and Darren - the saxophone player - sit at table by the window, eating.
Hey Walter, what time are you done tomorrow?
I have to present a paper at eleven. I should be done by twelve- thirty.
Cool.
(To the waiter) Hey man, could we get another order of this? (To Walter and Tarek) I love this food.
That's good. Because the Chinese are taking over the world.
That's not gonna happen.
It's already happening. One day our kids will be going to China for jobs. Ask Walter.
Darren and Tarek look at Walter.
You think that's true?
Walter is put on the spot.

Well...if China continues to threaten the wage earners in the first-world economies by keeping wages down, then it's really just a matter of time. What they buy they inflate. What they sell they deflate. But then you have to ask the question `who's paying the cost?'. And the answer is the Chinese people.
Beat.
You see?
Tarek continues eating. 36
Walter is presenting his paper.
Walter is walks out of the building talking to a FEMALE COLLEAGUE.
Hey, Walter!
Walter and the Female Colleague turn. Tarek is standing a feet away holding both drums. Walter nods and says good bye to the Colleague who looks bit confused. Walter walks over to Tarek.
How did the presentation go?
Fine. Thanks.
Cool. Guess what? I found an apartment in Brooklyn. We can move in on Monday.
That's good.
Yeah. It's small but it's a nice building. I just hope Zainab likes it.
I think she will as long as no else lives there.
Tarek laughs.
I think you're right. Come on, let's go. You should take off the name tag.
Oh. Yeah. Thanks. 37
Walter takes off his name tag and they start to walk.
Are you hungry?
Yeah. I'm starving. Do you like shwarmas?
Uh...yeah. I like sharmas.
Shwarmas.
Yeah.
They walk across the park.
Walter and Tarek are finishing lunch. Tarek reaches into bag and takes out a SMALL BAG.
Here. This is for you. For letting us stay.
Thank you.
Walter takes it and opens it. It's a CD.
